bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, January 16, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Truby that he is going to Cuba for a conference, but will not have time to do much with yellow fever research. Hench writes that the Cuban government has money to clean-up the site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, January 16, 1952
div1.opener:
January 16, 1952
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Just a hasty note. I have been working frantically during the holidays
trying to finish two papers. I leave today by train for Miami and then
Havana. I am attending a small international conference on nutrition
and metabolism and am speaking there.

I am so very tired that I will have practically no time to do much on
my yellow fever hobby; however I will get in touch with three or four
people and I understand that at least the Cuban Government has set
aside $25,000 to clean up the camp site and make it a little park,
although they have not set aside anything for the preservation of the
little shack, but I shall see what I can do.

How I wish you could be with us. Mary will be along. After the busy
week in Havana we are going to try and relax at VeraDoro Beach.

I have heard nothing more from Mrs. Standlee but I am delighted to have
your remarks. You certainly have her the information she needed.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
